Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Evaluating Conservation and Livelihood Outcomes from Community-Based Forest Management

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will examine the effectiveness of the United Nations' Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation (REDD+) program, which is an international funding mechanism to reduce emissions from tropical deforestation and degradation by simultaneously attaining emission-reduction, biodiversity-conservation, and livelihood-improvement goals. The project will investigate the REDD+ principles that giving local people the rights and powers to manage forest resources while promoting equitable sharing of carbon revenues will sustainably avoid tropical deforestation and forest degradation. This doctoral dissertation research project will assess the degree to which current REDD+ expansion in more than 60 tropical developing countries is occurring without sufficient understanding of whether and how to enhance simultaneous achievement of multiple outcomes. To contribute in filling these gaps, the doctoral student will conduct comparative case study assessment of communities with and without REDD+ interventions. He will combine mixed methods from the social and forest ecological sciences to empirically explore two research questions: (1) How do specific REDD+ interventions affect carbon, livelihood, and conservation outcomes separately and jointly? (2) What are the trade-off and synergistic relationships between carbon, conservation, and livelihood outcomes? The student will conduct a case study of REDD+ implementation in Tanzania, which was one of the first nine countries to pilot this program starting in 2009. Qualitative narratives will be used to explain the specific REDD+ interventions using data from focus group discussions, in-depth interviews, participant observations, and review of literature. Assessment of livelihood outcomes will rely on data from 240 household socioeconomic surveys. Assessment of carbon and conservation outcomes will use data from 60 systematic forest inventories. Appropriate statistical analysis will be used to determine relationships and statistical significance of differences in carbon, conservation, and livelihood outcomes between villages.

This project will analyze two emerging approaches to renewable resource management, payment for environmental services (PES) and recently decentralized community-based forest management (CBFM) programs, in order to assess whether and how their combination under REDD+ has avoided tropical deforestation. Successful REDD+ interventions promise affordable significant emissions reductions options for industrialized nations while protecting biodiversity and improving livelihoods of millions of forest dependent communities. The research will help formulate empirical policy recommendations to improve REDD+ effectiveness in nations piloting that UN program under similar PES and CBFM arrangements. The doctoral student will help develop a community level forest governance educational tool for tracking REDD+ impacts. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this project will provide support to enable a promising student to establish an independent research career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This doctoral dissertation improvement grant enabled a doctoral candidate -- Baruani Idd Mshale -- to achieve several contributions and achievements as summarized below. 

First, generated empirical evidence on whether and how could the recently introduced international program to reduce emissions from deforestation and forest degradation (REDD+) could concurrently reduce emissions, conserve biodiversity and improve livelihoods of forest dependent communities in the tropics. Findings from this project reveal that, in the miombo ecosystems of southeastern Africa, REDD+ is currently unable to deliver the triple wins concurrently. This is due to the biophysical nature of miombo ecosystems, institutional factors, historical contexts as well as changing socio-economic contexts that make it more profitable to clear forests than maintaining standing forests. However, the project identified conditions underwhich REDD+ could deliver the intended benefits including: increased commitment of the international community to fund REDD+ projects instead of using voluntary carbon markets and addressing other challenges that make forest conservation a less rewarding activity such as equitable sharing of forest revenues such as from logging. 

Second, this study has demonstrated the importance of simultaenously assessing often competing conservation and livelihood outcomes from such intergrated conservation and development initiatives. Most existing studies have focused on assessing either conservation or livelihood outcomes separately. Concurrent assessment of conservation and livelihood outcomes received inadequate attention due to methodological differences and disagreements between disciplines, and field logistical challenges among others. This study has shown under what conditions REDD+ interventions could achieve the triple win benefits (climate, livelihoods and conservation benefits) and where they fail, what causes the failure and how to make it work. 

Third this study contributes to the emerging focus on strengthening causal relations in conducting impact evaluation. This was achieved through a combination of qualitative and quantitative statistical analaysis. The qualitative methods were applied to understand and analyze the specific aspects of the intervention and provide narratives that explains the reported relationships. Usually when an intervention is introduced in an area, there could be other interventions and forces that may also attain the same intended outcomes or may be competing to hinder effectiveness of the intervention in question. In this study, all possible confounding factors were considered and analyzed through detailed qualitative investigations. As a result, this study makes important methodological contributions in terms of choosing appropriate variables and indicators for assessing relationships between interventions and outcomes. 

Moreover, given the timing of this study -- conducted when REDD+ pilot phase was just concluding, the findings have bee useful in informing REDD+ design and implementation in similar contexts. Specific recommendations included: whether and how to make avoided deforestation a competitive land use against traditional land uses of crop farming and selective logging; how to maximize the effect of the meagre carbon payments generated from miombo ecosystems; how to facilitate effective collaboration between local residents and external actors given the history of enmity and distrust between conservation agencies and local people
